body.p:
Your letter of March 7th is
received but I have no time to send a
lengthened reply. The cause of my silence is
not sickness, I am, thank God, in good health;
Every moment of the day is however so occupied
with Synagogue and School that I have no
leisure to write. I have a sacred duty to perform;
to lay by what may serve to keep my poor
wife in case of my death, ממתנות בשר ודם. She is
a hopeless invalid, and I want to screen her, while
I have the power to work, from the cold charity
of the world. Otherwise I would not labor 11
hours a day at school-keeping in this Enervating
climate. Often do I reproach myself with
neglecting my old friends, but Even when disposed
to take up the pew, I am physically unable.

I am not disposed to find fault with you
for your unasked opinion on the subject of the
calling to the Sepher of the בר מצוה “Bar Mitzvah” JE transcription. I regret you
have been appealed to, and hope you have not

p.rend: The following is written in the right bottom corner of the page.

body.p:
given a decided opinion on the subject. When
I was first here, no boy was ever called up
before being confirmed, and the plan was so far
beneficial that every boy who came to Sepher was
acquainted by with the leading principles of his faith.
Things changed for the worse during my absence,
and I have had enough to do, to bring matters with
a proper train. Your interference, well meant
as I am sure it is, will only weaken my hands.
I do not care a straw for confirmation, except
as a means of Enabling me to impart, months before the ceremony takes place, religious instruction,
at least its chief Elements. The Sunday School
is very good in its way, but it is not sufficient
for the purpose. The child you allude to, was
brought up in N/O, and did not know anything.
The Bar Mitzva, under such circumstances is
a sin and a mockery. But what is the Bar
Mitzvah? If Israel was יום טוב, why was
the Bar Mitzvah instituted? It is clearly a
Rabbinical mode of Confirmation, prefaced as it
has always been by sound religious instruction.

Unless this be erroneous, and I shall be very
glad if you will set me right, in case I am
wrong in this view, confirmation stands on
the same footing as the old method of
instruction, and as the ancient mode of giving
the boy a fulness? of knowledge before his 13th year
is no longer possible, I, and others, situated
as I am, must do our best to substitute something
Else before calling up to Sepher, in order that
the Bar Mitzvah, as in many Congregations,
may not dwindle away with a meaningless
ceremony, only connected with new clothes,
a gold watch, and a good breakfast, d?,
or dance. The child in question is nevertheless
so hopelessly stupid, that, since the receipt of your
last, I have resolved on calling him to Sepher without
preparatory confirmation. My nephew David,
whose Bar Mitzvah is at hand, I intend to confirm.
And then, I am sure, people here will be as anxious
for its reintroduction, as they were favorable to it
in former times. The Reform party here is
bestirring itself, and it will need all my prudence

savoir dire and savoir faire to prevent and outbreak
similar to what has occurred in Curacao. The party
wishes to go to extreme lengths, an organ, Marks's
prayer Book and other ultras are spoken of.
Another party who want no minister, but simply
a reader to marry and bury them is on the watch
to create disturbances, and bring about a separation.
The Congregation cannot support two Synagogues.
The By Laws are also against such a step. There
is much talk about petitioning the government
to repeal these By Laws. Should that be done,
“Othello's occupation's gone.” For neither party could
give me my present salary, which is barely able
to support me in this extravagantly dear place.
I want no organ, and nor do I want Marks's Prayer
Book. It would be laughable, were the affair not
so serious, to hear the crude notions of the young and
the old on this topic, Reform. Some of the hitherto
hyper-orthodox, among the rest, the party who
addressed you on the case of the Bar Mitzvah,
advocate the most incongruous measures. I keep
silence and have given no opinion except the
organ and Prayer Book. At the proper time it
must, by Law, be referred to me. But unless there be
something like unanimity, and no pr likelihood of
discussion, I will not give my adhesion to any
proposals for changing our present system of
worship which is working admirably. You are
happily ignorant of the perfidy and treachery of
Curacaoleans. Do not heed what they write you, they
are not to be trusted. They are injudicious friend, and
are terable? enemies
and the turn of a straw changes

body.p:
them from one to the other. You can now
comprehend the position I am placed in. The
question was put to you out of pique against me, not from any religious motive. I guessed
it would be done and was therefore not surprised at
nor angry with, the contents of your letter.

I am about sending you some money for
the dozen Bibles and the few Prayer Books had
last year. But I have no memorandum of the
cards of Creeds &c sent me at same time. I
wrote you of having received the missing
Books p “Responsible,” but as I have no
place to keep them in, I intend handing them
to my David Piza to dispose of in your
accot?. They have been damaged by sea-water
and must be sold considerably under the usual
price.

I must now conclude with wishing you שמחת
פסח, in which Mrs. N.—her mother, and David
join, with remembrances to old friends with whom
we spent Hebrew a quarter of a century ago.
